netsquid.qubits.sparsedmtools

Tools for manipulating sparse density matrices, one of the available formalisms for shared quantum states held by qubits.

class netsquid.qubits.sparsedmtools.SparseDMRepr(dm=None, num_qubits=None)

Bases: DMRepr

Representation of a quantum state using a sparse density matrix.

Parameters:

  • dm (2D-array_like, optional) – An object that can be cast into a (2**n, 2**n) matrix.

  • num_qubits (int, optional) – The number of qubits of this qstate. Only used if array is None.

Raises:

TypeError – If the number of qubits given is not an integer.

supports_universal

A class attribute indicating this class does support universal quantum computation.

Type:

bool

supports_mixed_states

A class attribute indicating this class does support mixed quantum states.

Type:

bool

Notes

SparseDMState class uses the scipy.sparse.csr_matrix sparse matrix class (CSR: Compressed

Sparse Row) to store the sparse density matrices. The main advantages of the CSR format include efficient arithmetic operations (CSR + CSR, CSR * CSR, etc.), efficient row slicing, and fast matrix vector products. Disadvantages include slow column slicing operations (for which the Compressed Sparse Column [CSC] is recommended), the fact that changes to the sparsity structure are expensive (for which the Dictionary of Keys [DOK] and Row-based list of lists [LIL] sparse matrix classes are recommended.), and the memory usage of the CSR format scales similarly to a ket vector, i.e. ~ 2^n (a coordinate based [COO] format may be more efficient for large density matrices containing a few non-zero elements). In summary, the CSR format is considered to be ideal for our purpose, as, in general, arithmetic and matrix vector operations will likely occur most often.

Examples

>>> from netsquid.qubits.sparsedmtools import SparseDMRepr

The default quantum state is the \(\vert 0 ... 0 \rangle\) state, and can be created by specifying the number of qubits.

>>> dm1 = SparseDMRepr(num_qubits=1)
>>> print(dm1)  
SparseDMRepr(num_qubits=1, sparse_dm=
  (0, 0)    (1+0j))

It is also possible to spcify the state the representation should be initialized in.

>>> dm2 = SparseDMRepr(dm=[[0, 0], [0, 1]])
>>> print(dm2)  
SparseDMRepr(num_qubits=1,
sparse_dm=
  (1, 1)    (1+0j))

For convenience DM represetion have standard math operations defined. Addition and subtraction with numpy arrays is also supported.

>>> dm_epr = (dm1 + dm2) / 2
>>> print(dm_epr)  
SparseDMRepr(num_qubits=1,
sparse_dm=
  (0, 0)    (0.5+0j)
  (1, 1)    (0.5+0j))

Operations will return a new qrepr by default.

>>> dm_out, m, p = dm_epr.measure(index=0)
>>> m  
0
>>> p  
0.5
>>> dm_out  
SparseDMRepr(num_qubits=1,
sparse_dm=
  (0, 0)    (1+0j))
>>> print(dm_epr)  
SparseDMRepr(num_qubits=1,
sparse_dm=
  (0, 0)    (0.5+0j)
  (1, 1)    (0.5+0j))

If an inplace operation is desired, the ‘modify’ parameter can be set to True.

>>> dm_out, m, p = dm_epr.measure(index=0, modify=True)
>>> dm_out is dm_epr
True
>>> print(dm_epr)  
SparseDMRepr(num_qubits=1,
sparse_dm=
  (0, 0)    (1+0j))
static create_in_basis(list basis_indices, basis_operator=ops.Z)

Create a representation in a given basis and with given eigenvalues.

Parameters:

  • basis_indices (list of int) – A list containing indices of the eigenkets of the basis_operator.

  • basis_operator (netsquid.qubits.operators.Operator, optional) – A single qubit observable that defines the basis of the qubits. Default the computational (Z) basis.

Returns:

The representation of this state.

Return type:

SparseDMRepr

Raises:

  • ValueError – If the list of eigenvalues is emtpy. If the operator is not a single qubit observable.

  • IndexError – If an index indexes beyond the available eigenkets of the operator.

  • TypeError – If the basis_operator is not of type Operator.

discard(self, int index) → QRepr

Discard the qubit at the index.

Parameters:

index (int) – Index of the qubit to drop from the quantum state.

Returns:

The representation of the state.

Return type:

SparseDMRepr

fidelity(self, QRepr reference_state, indices=None, bool squared=False) → double

Calculate the fidelity between this quantum state and a reference representation.

Parameters:

  • reference_state (QRepr) – A representation of a quantum state.

  • indices (list or tuple of int or None, optional) – The indices that should be used in the fidelity calculations. Default: the entire state.

  • squared (bool, optional) – If True the squared fidelity is returned. Default False.

Returns:

Fidelity (or squared fidelity).

Return type:

float

Raises:

  • ValueError – If the indices are outside the range of this representation. If not all given indices are unique. If length of reference ket does not match number of qubits in this ket state. If the dimensions of the reference state don’t match a KET or DM state

  • TypeError – If the provided reference state is not of type QRepr.

gmeasure(self, indices, operators, rng=None, bool modify=False) → tuple

Measure at the indices with the operators.

Parameters:

  • indices (int, list or tuple of int) – The indices to measure at.

  • operators (list (or tuple) of Operator or Operator) – List of measurement operators with which to measure, or a single observable, i.e. an operator with valid projectors.

  • rng (RandomState or None, optional) – Random number generator to use. If None then get_random_state() is used.

  • modify (bool, optional) – If this instance should be modified, or a new instance should be created. Creates a new instance my default.

Returns:

  • SparseDMRepr – The representation of the state after applying the measurement.

  • int – The measurement result.

  • float – The probability of finding the measurement result.

Raises:

  • ValueError – If the indices are outside the range of this representation. If not all given indices are unique. If a operator doesn’t match the number of qubits.

  • RuntimeError – If no measurement operator has succeeded.

  • TypeError – If the operators are not given as a list or tuple. If the given operators aren’t of type Operators.

is_valid

If the representation matches all its constraints. Can be an expensive operation.

Type:

bool

log_operation(self, opname)

Log and count a quantum state operation.

Parameters:

opname (str) – Name of the operation.

measure(self, int index, observable=ops.Z, rng=None, bool modify=False) → tuple

Measure at the index with the observable.

Parameters:

  • index (int) – The index to measure at.

  • observable (Operator, optional) – The observable with which to measure. Default the computational (Z) basis.

  • rng (RandomState or None, optional) – Random number generator to use. If None then get_random_state() is used.

  • modify (bool, optional) – If this instance should be modified, or a new instance should be created. Creates a new instance my default.

Returns:

  • DMRepr – The representation of the state after applying the measurement.

  • int – The measurement result.

  • float – The probability of finding the measurement result.

Raises:

ValueError – If the indices are outside the range of this representation. If not all given indices are unique. If the observable is not Hermitian.

measure_discard(self, int index, observable=ops.Z, rng=None) → tuple

Measure at the index in a particular basis and discard it from this state.

Parameters:

  • index (int) – The index to act at.

  • observable (Operator, optional) – The observable to measure the qubit with. Default the computational (Z) basis.

  • rng (RandomState or None, optional) – Random number generator to use. If None then get_random_state() is used.

Returns:

  • DMRepr – The representation of the state after applying the operation.

  • int – Measurement result

  • float – Probability of measuring the result

Notes

Intended to be a more efficient method than just measuring and then discarding.

multi_operate(self, indices, operators, weights=None, rng=None, bool modify=False) → QRepr

Apply a (weighted) list of quantum operators to a list of qubits.

Parameters:

  • indices (list or tuple of int) – The indices to operate at.

  • operators (list or tuple of Operator) – The operators with which to measure

  • weights (list or tuple of float or None, optional) – Weights for each operator. The default (None) is for each operator to have a weight of 1.

  • rng (RandomState or None, optional) – Random number generator to use. If None then get_random_state() is used.

  • modify (bool, optional) – If this instance should be modified, or a new instance should be created. Creates a new instance my default.

Returns:

The representation of the state after applying the operations.

Return type:

SparseDMRepr

Raises:

ValueError – If the indices are outside the range of this representation If not all given indices are unique If a operator doesn’t match the number of qubits

num_qubits

The number of qubits this representation represents.

Type:

int

operate(self, indices, operator, bool modify=False) → QRepr

Operate on the qubits at the indices with the operator

Parameters:

  • indices (list or tuple of int) – The indices to operate at.

  • operator (Operator) – The operator with which to act.

  • modify (bool, optional) – If this instance should be modified, or a new instance should be created. Creates a new instance my default.

Returns:

The representation of the state after applying the operation.

Return type:

SparseDMRepr

Raises:

ValueError – If the indices are outside the range of this representation If not all given indices are unique If the number of indices doesn’t match the operator

reduced_dm(self, indices=None) → ndarray

Returns the reduced density matrix for the given indices.

This is the result of discarding all other indices.

Parameters:

indices (list or tuple of int or None, optional) – The selection of qubits to find the reduced state for. The order of the indices will define the vector space for the reduced state. Default the whole state.

Returns:

Density matrix representing the reduced density matrix.

Return type:

numpy.array

Raises:

ValueError – If the indices are outside the range of this representation. If not all given indices are unique.

smart_tensor(self, QRepr other, bool force_append=False) → tuple

Combine the data of this representation and another one.

In order to optimize the tensor product the order of the tensor product can be reversed.

Parameters:

  • other (QRepr) – Another representation of a quantum state.

  • force_append (bool) – If the optimizations must be disabled and other must be appended to self.

Returns:

  • QRepr – A new instance that combines the two representations.

  • bool – True if the order was changed, i.e. if other was prepended to self instead of appended.

Raises:

TypeError – If the representations to combine are not of the same type.

sparse_dm

The sparse density matrix representing this state.

Type:

csr_matrix

tensor(self, QRepr other) → QRepr

Combine the data of this representation and another one.

The tensor operation is also possible via the ^ operator.

Parameters:

other (QRepr) – Another representation of a quantum state.

Returns:

A new instance that combines the two representations.

Return type:

QRepr
